document:
Module 2 Topics
TCP fundamental attacks on the TCP protocol
Denial-of-Service attack
SQL injection attack
Cross-site scripting attack
Miscellaneous: Heartbleed, ransomware, cryptojacking

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
The Heartbleed Bug and Attack
Vulnerability in OpenSSL's TLS Heartbeat extension
OpenSSL underpins HTTPS for banking and secure transactions
Introduced 2012; publicly disclosed 2014

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Background: the Heartbeat Protocol
TLS/SSL provides secure channels
Heartbeat implements keep-alive to maintain sessions when idle
Mechanism: request → copy payload of declared length L → reply
Bug: implementation trusts declared length (L) instead of actual payload size

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
How the Response Packet Is Constructed
The amount copied depends on the length field
If the declared length exceeds actual payload size, extra memory is copied into the response

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Attack Launch – Concept
Send a heartbeat request with an inflated payload length
Receiver copies more bytes than present → memory disclosure in response packet
Leaked data may include credentials, keys, or user info

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Attack Launch – Normal Length Example
Length field set to match actual payload (e.g., 0x0016 for 22 bytes)
No extra data leaked when lengths match exactly

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Launch the Heartbleed Attack – Oversized Length
Increase declared length (e.g., 0x4000 = 16 KB > 22 bytes)
Receiver copies excess memory into the response
Repeated requests may reveal different memory regions over time

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Attack Results
Server memory is exfiltrated in heartbeat responses
Leaked data depends on what resides in affected buffers at time of request
Multiple attempts can yield different secrets

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Fixing the Heartbleed Bug
Update OpenSSL to patched versions
Apply bounds checking to validate declared length against actual record size before copying

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Fixing Heartbleed – Bounds Checking Logic
If (declared_length + overhead) > actual_record_length → drop packet, no reply
Constants: 1 (type) + 2 (length) + 16 (min padding) = 19 bytes overhead
Prevents memcpy from over-reading memory buffers

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Story: Bounds Checking and Game Design
Illustrative analogy on how strict bounds checks prevent logic exploits
Security lesson: validate untrusted lengths and sizes before processing

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Cryptojacking – Definition
Unauthorized use of a victim’s CPU/GPU to mine cryptocurrency
Two routes: malware (via social engineering) and browser-based scripts (malvertising/injected JS)
Symptoms: overheating, high CPU, sluggish performance

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
How Cryptojacking Works
Attacker injects a mining script in a website or ad
When loaded, the script runs mining code in the browser tab
Often no files written to disk; runs as long as page/tab remains open
Pools aggregate mined shares over many victims

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Preventing Cryptojacking
Use VPN and up-to-date web filtering
Train users to resist phishing
Ad-blocking/anti-cryptomining extensions
Endpoint protection for known coin miners
Maintain browser extensions; MDM for mobile controls

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
DNS and Attacks – Overview
DNS is the Internet’s phonebook (name → IP)
We cover hierarchy, zones, servers, queries, and attack surfaces
Attacks include DoS and spoofing/cache poisoning

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
DNS Domain Hierarchy
Tree-like structure with ROOT (“.”) at top
TLDs (e.g., .com) followed by second-level domains (e.g., example.com)
IANA oversees root zone; DNS maps names to IPs for hosts/services

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
DNS Zones vs Domains
Zone groups contiguous domains/subdomains under one management authority
A domain can be split into multiple zones for scalability
Subdomains may maintain their own zones on different name servers

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Authoritative Name Servers
Each zone has authoritative servers (master/primary and slave/secondary)
Master stores original zone records; slaves maintain synchronized copies
These provide definitive answers for records in their zones

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
DNS ROOT Servers
13 logical root name servers (anycasted globally)
They serve delegations to TLD servers
If root servers were down, DNS resolution would be severely impacted

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Top-Level Domains (TLDs)
Infrastructure (.arpa), Generic (.com, .net), Sponsored (.edu, .gov, .mil, .travel), Country-code (.au, .cn, .fr)
Reserved TLDs: .example, .test, .localhost, .invalid

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
DNS Query Process
Local files (/etc/hosts, /etc/resolv.conf) checked first
Local resolver queries recursive DNS which iteratively consults ROOT → TLD → authoritative
Caching used with TTL to reduce load and latency

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Local DNS Files
/etc/hosts stores static name→IP entries
/etc/resolv.conf configures the local DNS server IP
DHCP often supplies resolver info automatically

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Local DNS Server and Iterative Querying
Starts at ROOT when it lacks cached answers
Receives referrals down the hierarchy (.net → example.net) until it reaches the authoritative server with the answer

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Emulating a Local DNS Server – Step 1
Query a ROOT server directly
ROOT replies with referrals (no direct answer) to relevant TLD name servers

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Steps 2–3: Ask TLD and Authoritative Servers
Ask a .net nameserver
Ask the example.net authoritative server
Finally obtain the answer (IP) and cache it with TTL

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
DNS Cache
Local DNS servers cache answers to speed resolution
Entries expire based on TTL values to ensure freshness

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
How Does Local DNS Learn Root IPs?
Answer: the root hints (zone file) preconfigured in resolvers
Used to bootstrap iterative queries to ROOT

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
DNS Attacks – Overview
Denial-of-Service: overwhelm local/authoritative servers → name resolution fails
DNS Spoofing: provide fraudulent IPs to redirect victims to attacker-controlled hosts

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Attack Surfaces in DNS
Multiple packets in queries/replies create spoofing points
Potential targets: user host, local resolver, TLD servers, authoritative servers
DoS can target each point; cache poisoning targets resolvers

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Attacks on Compromised Machines
If root is obtained on host:
Modify /etc/resolv.conf to point to malicious DNS
Modify /etc/hosts to override selected domains (e.g., bank site → attacker IP)

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Spoofing DNS Replies (LAN) and Cache Poisoning
Attacks on users: send spoofed replies appearing from local DNS before real replies
Attacks on resolvers: inject spoofed iterative replies to poison cache with attacker-controlled IPs

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Attacks on Nameservers – UltraDNS (2004)
DoS against a major DNS provider supporting Amazon, Walmart, Expedia
Outage lasted about an hour; highlighted DNS provider risk concentration

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Attacks on Nameservers – DNSPod (2009)
DDoS on Chinese DNS provider targeting Baofeng.com
When caches expired, Baofeng clients spammed DNS due to a software bug
Impact: network congestion across ~20 provinces (major incident)

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 6.pptx

document:
Attacks on Nameservers – Dyn (2016)
Large DDoS against DNS provider for many major sites (CNN, BBC, HBO, PayPal)
Botnets of IoT devices (e.g., cameras, baby monitors) used
Result: broad Internet service outages
